div.head: Vienna Museum.
div.p: Amid t a medley of antique masterpieces there is in this Museum an old oarpet of perfeot beauty, extreme finish, and of a pattern the most carious and the moat pare in Oriental, or rather Persian,-style that has yet been seen. The unknown artist who wrought it seferal centuries ago (some obsoare artisan of Teheran, or of the conntry of Jtbe Bakhtiars) conceived of marvellous unreal flowers, amongst which in Bupple and graœful postures trolio and fight the most varied animals of creation. This carpet, which was thoagbt to be aniqae in the world, is so no longer. Asa matter of fact, two yesrs ago, Messrs. T.A. 8partali and Co. sent to Vienna one of their best designers, with the special mission of making an exact oopy cf this oarpet In possession of the precious sketch, the firm appointed one of its most capable workmen to reproduce it Eighteen months were needed to terminate this work, but a oarpet was produced of a fiqish so inoom parab'e and so perfeot asoccess, that the meet fastidions taste admires it unreservedly. M. B. Subercaseanx, attaché of the Chilian Legation at Berlin, saw this marvellous carpet, and immediately purchased it This masterpieoe * wilbremsin in Cairo until Monday, 14th inat, and can be seen at Messrs; T.A. Spartali and Co.'s offioet, Rond Point Savoy Hotel

div.head:
FINDS AT MARIOUT
INTERESTING ARCHAEOLOGICAL DISCOVERIES.
div.p: In the conrae of soundings fur gypsum, on the estate of Mr. Emin Karam at Gaibaniah Marioot, Mr. A. Krieger has laid bare two fragments of a column of Assouan granite, of a diameter of 90 centimetre? and 3£ metres long, which aro covered with hieroglyphio inscriptions. The oolomn is of the epooh of Ramoses IP, 13th century B.C., from the foot that the oartoucha of that Pharaoh is repeated several times in the inscription. An epitaph to a Roman oitizan, of the house of the Jalii, inso/ibed in the tribe of Cornelia, was also found not very far away.

Professor Breccia is on the spot making further researches. Although nothing startling is to be expeo'el, it is almost oertain that montmeots will be foond of interest to the history and topography of Regio Mareotica.

div.head: EGYPTIAN FRONTIER MEASURES.
div.p: The Alexandria correspondent of ihe "Globe" say: The attachment of A1 Arish to the Government of Sinai has caused no diminution in the foods allowed by the Cairo Ministry for the detence of that forties», the staff of which will, it has just been decided, be deperdent on the War Ministry, together with a part of theoivil staff of the Penicsila. Tbe latter is being augmented, in order to oarry oat the policy of development contemplated by the Egyptian Government. The detachments of guards stationed at Taba and Akaba will, it is resolved, be reoroited from the Sudaneae battalions, on acoonnt of their oniqae familiarity with desert operations. A small contingent has been dispatohed from tbe Sudan to patrol the frontier poets. At the other, the Western, frontier of Egypt, negotiations are being opened with the Vali cf Tripoli, as tbe result of an understanding between Cairo and:*!]* Porte, with regard to the persistent attacks of the Benghazi Bédouins on tribes sabjeot to the Khedive. The Bgyptian Govern-' ment has notified Tripoli that a recurrence of these inoessant raids woald necessitate military measures of protection, reluotant as the Khédivial Ministry woald be to take them.

div.head: EGYPTIAN FOREIGN RELATIONS.
div.p: A correspondent writes :— The political status of Egyptians abroad, and especially in Turkey, is one of pecnliar interest. Nominally subjeota of the Saltan, their interests in Turkey are in the costody of a political agent or Kapn Kethudar. The agency in 8tamboul ocoapied by a locum tenons, Mahmoud Bey Shukeir, the vaoanoy being due to the opposition of the Saltan to the appointment of an Egyptian, as requested by the Khédivial Government, in the stead or the Turkish official who formerly oooopied the post. Before Akaba, this matter had not maoh importance from a political point of view, but it behovee qs as the tutelary power to provide a surer guarantee for Egyptians in Tarkey, than at present exists. Only last summer a Khédivial offioial of nofe was arrested on his arrival at Constantinople on snspioion of being the emissary of the Young Turks of Cairo. In the Ottoman capital the Egyptian oolouy is small, but in 8yria, whither the Nile dwellers resort in considerable numbers every sommer, and in the Hedjaz, to which they perform their pilgrimage?, their political statas is now a question of direotaod urgent importance. I s»y "now" beoause the lessoD of Akaba has revealed to the Tarks that, whether the Egyptians like it or not, Great Britain is determined to rale Egypt, and to insist on the recognition of Bgyptian nationality. There is a possible alternative of the Saltan repudiating the Egyptians as his subjeota, in which case their political nonentity would be awkward, both to themselves and to the British position. It will therefore be interesting to note what conrse of action Lord Cromer will take, after he has abolished the Capitulations, touching this moot qoestion of Egyptian nationality. Bakallom !

div.head: CAIRO AS A WINTER RESORT.
div.p: Mr. Edward Dioey, C.B., in his weekly letter from Cairo to the "Daily Telegraph," in re ferring to the comparative slackness of the toarist incursion into Cairo in Deoember, says that this suggests a doubt whather the Cairo authorities do as maoh to attract tourists as they ought to do, in the interests of the city. There has, he says, "recently been a aerie? ot letters in the Cairene Press complaining of the absence of drives in and about the town, which, after all, is the headquarters of the touriBt immigration. The complaint is well justified, bat there are many, and to my mind well nigh insuperable difficulties in making carriage drives throughout a country where oarriage roads cannot be said to exist. After all, visitors do not come to Cairo for the sake of making excursions by carriages or motors on roads which, at the lest, most from the nature of the soil te grievously inferior to those snr- ronnding any European capital. The one danger to the popularity of Cairo as a wintèr resort lies in the possibility of the town being deprived of its attractions as a residence by tha bcildiog mania, which has been brought aboot by the extraordinary rise in the price of 'and"

div.head: COLLISION IN THE CANAL
div.p: Yesterday morning, while the French steamer Ville da Majonga was moored in the Canal in order to let the S.S. Den of Ogil pass, owing to its being a narrow part of the Canal, the latter ran into the French boat, and both vessels were more or less damaged. The Ville de Majnnga, which is bound to Madagascar, is sailing from Suez to-day, after having been surveyed.
The Italian cruiser Calabria, having on board H.R.H. the Doke of Udina, who is on hia way home from a tour round the world, is expeoted to arrive at Goes very shortly.

div.head: A BAD YEAR
div.p: In their seventh annual report, which is to be presented to the shareholders at the eighth ordinary general meeting of the Egyptian Cotton Mills,Limited, to bo held at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, London, RC., on Thursday, the 17th inst., the directors regret that the good results of last year have not been repeated in this, the aooonnts on the 30 th September, 1906, showing a loss of £930.0*. U. sterling.They attribute this, in a great measure, to the heavy stocks, which had aoonmolated daring the time the company were completing the transfer of their goods from their late agenoy, and opening np communications with its oustomers direct nnder the new arrangement, It was, however, impossible for the company to oarjy those heavy stocks for any long period, and the moment, at which they were obliged to get rid ot them, was unfortunately a period of depression on this market, and conae* quently prioes realised did not cover cost of manofaotnriog.Tbis had the farther result of limiting the mill's oatpat daring this time. For laok of liquid money the company have never been able to take advantage of a drop in price of raw cotton, to lay in stooks of it, or to hold any Btook of finished goods in between seasons. The cost ot prodnotion has beea inoreaaed, owing to the poor quality erf the raw material last year. Native labour has been dearer and not so abondant as in the past, owing to the great demand for manual labour. Prioes of all stores and materials used have been higher. The shareholders' liability has been muoh rednoed this year. Stooks at present are very small, and the position generally at ^he dose of the year iB maoh healthier than it has hitherto been. Gradually the goods manofaoto red in the mill have been getting better known aod more liked in Bgypt and the conoern oan now work to order, whereas in the past it has been necessary to manufacture into stock. No depreciation has been written off the plant and maobinery, but the latter has been kept in good working order by liberal expenditure from revenue. The oouBtantly increasing vaine of tbe company's land sinoe its pnrohase may be regarded as, in some measure, a setoff against the depreciation that has taken place on the remainder of the property since oan menciDg work.

The duty is to be raised to 1001 the hectolitre at 50deg. centigrade, being augmented above or lowered if below that degree. div.head: SIR WILLIAM GARSTIN'S REPORT.
div.p: Sir William Garstin, who returned to Cairo reoently from the Sadan from a journey up the Blue Nile as far sooth as Rosaires, was mnch impressed by the improvement everywhere visible in the condition of the people sinoe he visited the river in 1899. At that time the effeota of dervish rule were very evident. The villages were mostly in ruins, the population was in hiding, and a few soanty crops were all that conld be seen.

At present there is an almost continnons line of onltivation on botbr slopes of the river from Khartoum to the point where the dense forest commences—a distanoe of several hundred miles. The villages are nameronu and prosperous looking. The inhabitants own large herds of oattle, sheep and goats.

The chief need of this part of the Sudan is railway commnnioation with Khartonm. Owing to the fall in the water levels navigation of the Blae Nile is impossible for qaite half the year, and the people in the sonth are unable to fiod a market for their agricultural produoe owing to the laok of means of transport Tbe Gezira a (provinoe between the Bine and White Niles immediately south of Khartonm) contains an immense area of magnifioent land.
With a system of artificial irrigation it should become one of the first wheat producing countries of the world. The only thing which militates against the prosperity of this region

its unhealthino-s. In the onrrent year the proportion of sick at eaoh of the southern stations was exceptionally high, and rivalled, if it did not surpass, that of the Bahr-el-Ghazal The country Is now pelioed by local levie*, chiefly reoroited from the Arab tribes. The experiment, so far, has turned ont a great soo- 0688.

rains an Caire qui laisserait 9,000 livres de béuéfice net.
Des aflaires ont été faites également en ao- tions Héliopolis qui ouvrent'à 850, atteignent 370 et clôturent à 860, vendeurs. La part de fondateur s'inscrit à £ 14, acheteurs.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lord Rathmore, a member of the board of direotora of the Bat k of Egypt, and Mr. Greville Palmer, another director, and also chairman of Egyptian Estates, Limited, arrived at Port Said yesterday by the P. & 0. steamer and came on to Cairo last night Lord Rathmore is staying at the Savoy Hotel, and Mr. Greville Palmer is staying at Abbassieh with his daughter, Mrs. Badgeon.
Lord and Lady Rathdonnell are passengers by the steamer Orontee, which is dae at Port- Said to-morrow.
Saad Pasha Zaghloal, who fias returned from Upper Egypt, had an interview with Lord Cromer yesterday.
We hqar that the salary of Mr. A.L. Webb, C.M.G., Under Secretary of State for Irrigation to the Ministry of Public Works, has been raised to LE. 2,000.
Lady Blomfield, who has now bappi'y recovered from her reoent illness, is leaving for Cairo on Saturday in order to reouperate her strength.
Mrs. .Bullock will not be "At Home" on Sunday next, 18th inst.
The Khedive has conferred the rank of Lewa on Mahmoud Pasha Rifaat, sub-director of the Prisons Department.
Shoiarabati Bey, chef de .la Délégation da Contentieux de l'Etat at Alexandria, has been promoted Khédivial connsellor.

Mr. Arthor Fell, M.P., Mrs. Fell, and the Misses Fell, after a few days' stay at Shepheard's Hotel, have gone up the Nile, and will visit Syria and Palestine before returning to Lanriston House, Wimbledon.
Capt. Plassy, 1st Batt King's Own Boottiah Borderers, and Lient. W. J. Mannsell, 1st Batt Lancashire Fasi liers, leave for England by the transport Plassy from Port Said on the 14th inst

Sir Alfred Sandison, whose death at Constantinople after a long illness is reported, was er, 1. H were Norwegian. 10 Roumanian, 8 a well-known figure in Constantinople diplo- Swedish, 8 Tanisian, 6 Danish, 2 from Samosi ; matio and offioial society. He entered the society

Diplomatic Service in 1859, was appointed Dragoman to the Embassy at Constantinople in Janaary, 1860, and was Aoting Consul at Jeddah from Maroh till August, 1867, at Trebizond from May till August, 1868, aod at Brnsa from September, 1868,'till May, 1869. He was granted the local rank of Oriental Second Ssoretary at the British Embassy in the Tarkish capital in April 1874. He received the honour of Knighthood in 1878. and retired on a pension in Angnst 1R94. Sir Alfred was the recipient of the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Medjidieb.

div.head: EGYPT AND CUBA
div.p: The "New York Herald" (Paris), in a leading article dealing with the sitnatkm in Cuba, says the difficulty sbonld be faoed boldly and 1 a straightforward protectorate established over Coba similar to the protectorate that Eogland has established offer Egypt. The results of such • policy in Cuba wonld undoubtedly be identical with the result* iriras produced in Bgypt. Duriug the past twenty foor years Egypt has developed at an amâxirg rate of progress, and has enjoyed a political stability, a material prosperity, a real freedom from interference, that is onparalle'dd in its modern history. The Cabans should be allowed complete liberty to el»0t their own Government, jaat aathedy- nastio rights of the Khedive and the essential liberties of his people are respeoted. Butjost as the British Représentatifs, actually Lord Cromer, is above the native Government to supervise the exeoation by Bgypti&n agency of the measures diotated by sound principles of public administration, so in Cuba, an Ameri can representative sbonld be above the Cuban Government to protect the soperior interests of the United Sûtes. Andjostaa obedience to the will of the sovereign Power is assored in Egypt by the presence of the British army of oooopatiee, the American represenUtive's authority sbonld be opbeld in Cnba by an tffeotire American military foroe."

div.head: S.P.C.A

div.p: Tin following is the report on the working of (be Ghirgeh branoh of the S.P.C.A. from

This branch was formed at the beginning of. the year 19^6. hot aotive operations- were not coeumecced till the mouth of April. The great need fbr this branch is emphasised by the faot that oat of several handred donkey* examined daring the year, not more than 8% could sh w a back that had not at one tinn or another suffered from severe galls. Owing to the oi tagging- interest and activity of the late Moudir of Gbirgeb, Ibrahim Bay Nabesh, an smtiont of L£. 775.803 was oolleoted, and n targe piece of land fbr the ereotion of a stable granted by the Government Unfortunately, ibrahim Bey was transferred last May to another provinoe, and from the date of his departure native interest in the society has almost entirely oeased, not a single na'ive having taken the trouble to inspeot the stables or to leat;n how the work was progressing. v After the grant of land and the oolleetion oi BQoh a substantia' sum of money, a committee was convened to disonss aa to thé building of a snitablè stable. Unhappily, however, the mem bers ooald not agree on tha sobj ,ot of cost, a large seotion wishing to expend the whole of the money oolleoted on b Riding, while a smaller seotion demanded that a humbler building be ereoted and a proper reserve be pot by to meet the yearly nnavoidable loss, for the next few years.The matter was thereupon shelved and has remained practically in absyat.oe ever since. However, a temporary shelter was ereoted at Ghirgeh and another at Sohag, and up to the end of Dioember 341 animals passed through the hands of tbesqoiety. Of tha-e27 had to be destroyed, or 8%, a very high parce itage; 290 h »ve been discharged as oared; 2 have died nnder treatment, while at tho close of 'hi year 16 were remaining nnder treatment.

A noticeable diffrrence Las already bare observed in the state of tin animals in the mndirieh.bad oases of cruelty being very much rarer. It is hoped that this improvement will continue and that an andsr itandiDg will sturdy be arrived ^t by the committee as to building.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
JUNIOR CHAMPION8HIP POLO TOURNAMBNT.
div.p: The entries for this tonrnament, which com- mences to-morrow, are most satisfactory, no less than nine teams competing, so we may look forward to a very interesting tonrnament. Wè regret very much that the Rifle Corps, from Alexandria, have not entered-a team, as an entry from this sporting regiment wonld have been very popular. The Coldstream Guards have entered three team», and this speaks for itself. With the Ianiskilling Dragoons, ''The Tigers," "Egyptian Armj," "Gunner»," tha "Nondescripts," and a team from the K.S.C., we havo the nine entries.

The King's Own Scottish Borderers have several very keen players, and with their colonel to lead them, woald hive pat in a very good team, but they nofortanately have been enable to collect sufficient ponies to* compete. Their colonel, by the way, was playing polo here 18 years ago. We wish him every aaooess and weloome the return of a downright good sportsman.

The polo match yesterday, England versas Sootland, was rather a disappointment, neither Bide being folly represented. It resulted in a somewhat one-sided match, England scoring six goals to love. Capt. Dnnbar was for once in a way off his game. The teams were : England, Major Neil Haig, Mr. K. Mtrsham, Mr. Nixon, and Mr. Spier ; Scotland, Capt D mbar, Mr. Gibb», Mr. MacGiilivrsy, and Mr. Eden.
We are glad to be able to report that the stewards of the K.8 C. have decided to remain in office at any rate for the rest of this season, and we hope for many sea so: a to come.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE
LE JONGLEUR DE NOTRE DAME
div.p: Pbom oua Theatrical Corbkspondeht. ) Massenet's "Jongleur de Notre Daaae" it a delight*01 opera. Poonded on an old legend, its story is chatming. The luckless, hungry, strolling phyer tarns monk for the take of a dinner, envies all the oraftsmen who offer their gifts to our Lady, and at last in despair offers his poor tricks and lays. 8he accepts them, and he dies miraculously blessed by her, in ah ec'itasy of raptarons humility. The masio has more than a touch of Gonnod, and ot Wagner, but Masbeuet never loses his own talent. He is appropriate, foil of subdoed wit, wi'h even a touch cf malicious irony here and there, and, all through, a oertaio appreciating balanoe of admiration for the lovely airs he gives or sets, which saves tham from endue sweetness or complication. The opening is of a fugal nature, very delicately treated, bat with strength, and later, the least Ej»picion of modern Italy in the hints at long drawn, slowly resolved drnonances. There are chatming arias, the brother oook's praise , of his trade and his abbey, and the juggler's ; renaneiatiou y and all the choral work is charming, especially the 3-note ending, not so fiuite and hush as the fall oloee ; it com** to ths dominant from the upper note, not from the lower note: the effect ii less sombre, but yet. fioaL The jewel of the 2nd act is the old legend I (baritone) sung by Lureo (the oook) to the jaggler, an old, old air perfectly set. M. Loreo waanofcingoed voice, though, and the oreheatra} could not handle the delioate masio. The mingling qf chorus and tenor, .earlier in the aot (the ohoir praotice icine) was charmiug ; and most olever. Tha opening of ths last aot( suggested "Tristan"—the Bhephard music,—| and, still more, "Dame Holds,'' in a délierons antiphon al duet. The songs to the Virgin are ' apt-. Varied, nowin schorz\ now in roulades, just at the right moment. One of them is aj pastoral, another a romance of levs, another a ; war-song. and all the ending is fall of fl :e oolonrtDg.

M. fontaine was faultless for aotieg, pre- « Bence, singing (for technique, phrating, and expression). But he could not oast away the unsympathetic stifle! tone which now anti, again makes ore think be isn't even a tenor, I much lees a well-trained tenor. His notes ar»*j never dree. M. Loreo, the oook, w»s rather i hoarse and thin, without the tone he usually j has. M. Durand, the prior, war, as nsaal, correct and imposing, sod, at moments, hue. M. Chappelou, the soulptor brothe-, and M. Gordin, the painter, were excellent : their noting—indeed the acting of «veryone— werf admirable The chorus had shocking moments all through the 2nd and 3rd aot, and the J orchestra never seemed to have a propet hold ! of masio—or notes ! It only showed how perfeet the opera mast be if really well done. Of ooorsetbe abseaoe of femininity is quaint —bat then, in a convent! And after all we had ' Cendrillon" last weak as a set-off. I wonder if Massenet thought- of the one when he wrote the other. It sometimes seemed like it.

div.p: I seethe Abbas Theatre is going to provide Italian opera in a few days. Apparently com- ' pany and repertoire are muoh the same as in I the summer of last year. There is plenty of] Verdi and Puccini, also ' Lncia," "Mefistof de," and ths "Hngaenots." These last three ar*, ' surely, rather a dangerous trio. "Lucia" (in which I once heard one Mile Svicher—her voioe, of nearly three ootaver, was sapable of the most astonishing feats) is apt to be dull and gloomy if not very very wreil sung. "Me- fistofale" is the easiest of all operas to mishandle and to misunderstand. Its moments of olimsx and snhtlety, its intellectuality and depth, on be quite «poil*, as they were last year, bj| those who cannot stage it, oarry through the orohedratior, or sing the parts so as to get the realj>alance of the whole. But if the conductor u really good, and if they get Signor Carlo Walter from Alexandria to sing the title part, it may go well. The 'Huguenots" has too much volume and romance for moat companies. The voices moet be very trne and good, and the chores axaot and enthusiastic. We bsve three old friends, Signori Battain, Veoobion», and Amghetti. The last-named is not good, Veoobiooi eiogi some parti wel', but has rather a narrow conception of them, Battain is delightfsl : he may not know all aboat opera singing and aoting. bat hii tone is pe faction itself in every note. div.head: SRANDING OF THE TANGISTAN
div.p: After the British steamer Tangistar, as reported in my last, had get eft the reefs and gone to Port Sndsro, fhe Controller cf Sudan Port*, Drury Bey, sent a number of divers to the spot where the vessel had stranded and had thrown overboard a large quantity of cargo. A great deal of this cargo is floating about, and is being collected and loaded on satnbDks to be sent to Snekin Custom Honse, where it will be sold by auction. The divers recovered a goqd many cases and bales that had sunk, containing doth, ironware, and rifle*, besides several esses of ammunition, all intended for India. The Tangiatan is being tho- roochly examined. S une slight repairs to her bottom plates will have to be done before she can proceed.

div.head: Athlatlo Sports.
div.p: The annual athletio sports took place here On Boxing Day and were a great success. The committee deserve muoh credit for the way in which the events were'got through. The Governor of the Red Sea Province*, Mlralai Hawker Bey, tcok part in one of the horse races and obtained first prise. The foot rac9 for officers was' won by Sagboolagb&ssi Lutfi Effaodr, of the 6th Battalion, E. A. Sudaneao Pilgrim».

The British S.8. Safari, of Bombay, which was lately purchased by the Khédivial Mail Co., arrived here for the first time from Jeddah on the 2tth inst. to eonvey to Jeddah Sudanese pilgrims, of whom there were 3,000 awaiting transport here. One thousand embark- ed<on the Safari, whioh left yesterday for Jeddah. About 200 pilgrims are leaving by the Khédivial steuner MthalLh to day for Jeddah. TUe remaining pilgrims wilt await another steamer, which has been wired for.

div.head: A No tabla Pilgrim.
div.p: The number of pilgrims from the interior of the Sudan hafegreatly increased this year owing to railway tioilities, and is likely to further increase. Among the pilgrims who hate 1 ft ly the Mahall h is one of the Emirs of Aly Dinar, the Sultan cf Darfur, who nF taking wi'h him several oases of ooitly presents foil the Hedjsz authorities.

div.head: THE HANDLING OF-EGYPTIAN COTTON.
div.p: An interesting description of. the method of handling Egyptian ootton at the Manchester Doeks appears in the'excellent annual commercial supplement issued by the "Manchester Guardian."

Within the long warehonses which line the quays at Salford a very large acreage is (the writer says) given up to the storing and handling of the great cargoes of ootton with which thefr are conBtantly being fed out of the holds of Steamers arriving from America and from Egÿpt A sketch acoompaDying the article was taken looking across a floor on the first stofey of one of the newer warehouses, at which was being unladen a cargo from Egypt. The rootn, one of a low and lengthy aerie, is painted white, with wooden beams end pillars bound with ijon. . Wide doors open along its outbr walls, whence the ootton may be unloaded by cranes direct from the vessels lying below and alongside.

The fl jor is specked with stray pnffs of ootton froii the armies of bales that stand about, end upwards and shoulder high, in serried ranks. Little tin flags with numbers on them differentiate the lot*, and olear lanes are left amSngst them along whioh the employés may whéel them on tracks to the scales, a solid ms- ohisa which lifts the bale between two other- wis# ionooent-looking fiat hands that have spiles in theirpalms. Numbers of 56lb. weights contpose the counterbslance. Each bile is labelled lat the desk nearby with its weight, which may be anything between six and eight owt. ; dat*»gj, if any, is also notified, the bale already having had a number of marks steooillol on it in previous stages of its career. Many of the steA bands are lying about on the floor ; they will be carefaliy garnered, for they are very valuable "waste." The Bnap they give as a laden truck (heavy enough to shake the floor) pastes over them is qaite a local note.

div.head: MOSLEM JOURNALISTS.
div.p: Ib addition to the new Mahomedan daily newspaper to be established in Locknow early in-tiie New Year, it is now proposed to found another in Calcutta, where the need for a journal to represent the views of the Moslem coudmunity has long been felt. It is proposed that an E-iglLh journalist of the highest qualifi cations should be appointed editor of this new J Calèutta paper, but that the rest of the staff should be drawn from the Mahomedan raoe. A capital of £100,000 will in all probability be sobtoribed for the loatdlng'of this paper.

div.head: SLEEPING SICKNESS CURES.
div.p: A striking conteet is said to have arisen in Section with the bestowal of tbe prize of ffttOO instituted by Kiog Leopold for the discovery of a remedy for sleeping siokness. Dr. Vaitoampeaheat.a Belgian scientist,ha* actually op red two diseased men, but it is also said ibat Dr. Koeh's recent dirooveries in Africa hav# rendered considerable service to the work of rèsearch.Both thus teem entitled to the prize, and-the Congo authorities are at a loss to know to whom they shall offer it

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazbtt* ''

Si*,. I bava seldom read a more astounding accumulation of confoaed statement,', misunderstood and- petvertnd fcrtsts, and pernicious doctrines, than is contaiircd in the letter of "Britannioos," which appeared in your issue of the 4th instant. Tbe language and style are those of a Labour member,or a pupil-teacher in a Board school, and the sentiments and views »how that the writer is either a member of the Cobden Club or is at least io full sympathy with the ideas of that irrational and unnational association. It is also evident that he has a deep seated grudge against Australia and Australians, upon whom he poori out the vials of his wrath. He asserts that tbey are under so obligation, to Great Britain, the natnre cf which, however, he forgets to mention. I am no Australian, and bold no brief for their defence, but I vent a re to assert that whatever debt they may have owed to the motbeiwoaa- try has been more than wiped oot by the loyd and generous manner in which tbey came to her assistaDoc, and gave their money and blood freely on her behalf, in the days of her stress and difficulties. Probably "Britannioua" is a pro Boer, and look* upon the Soutfa African War as a crime. If so, he is one of those people with whom it is useless to attempt to argue.

It would take too long te analyze the va- tiooe propositions laid down in bis letter, though nothing would be easier than their refutation. But there are one or two statements whjoh are so startlingly absurd thst I venture to ask you for spaoe to expose them. 'BritaaniiW says: "It is now odIj " by courtesy that Germany and some other " countries permit us to trade under the fa- " voured-nation olaases, for legally oolonial " high duties on their goods put os out of " the category. As they are part of the Em- " pire all our home exports to these foreign " countries ooald justly be put on the prohi- " bitivp, or highest, scales.'' (The grammar of this last senteooe is defeotive. but the meaning is intelligible). -It "Britannious" really so ignorant or so credulous as to believe that Germany, or any other country, is aoting out of "ooartesy" in admitting British goods on the "most-favourad nation" level Î How his German friends of the Cobden Club would laogh at suoh an idea. They know perfectly well that to place British goods on the highest scale would be to tffjrd to the British nation the objeot-lesaon which alcne is reqaired to convert the people to Mr. Chamberlain's views, and that "retaliation" and Tariff Reform—than which nothing is more dreaded by German trade-~woaldquiokly be enforced. As a convinced Tariff Reformer I earnestly wish that the objeot-lesson might be given.

"Britannions" talke of the-îgenerous acceptanoe by the aggrieved Powers*' of the excuse that we conld not compel self governing colonies to reduce their tariff, and regards it as a meritorious aot on the part of Ger many that, when Canada gave a preference on British goods, the Germans retaliated on Canada t^lone bat did not plaoe all the British Empire out of the favoured-nation clause. Suoh language is "all bankum." Of oourse the Germans knew perfectly will on which side their bread was buttered, and it was not likely that, an aooount of their comparatively iDsignifioant trade with Canada, they woald do anything to endanger their great and gowiog trade with Great Britain and the rest of the Empire. To attribute their action to ooartesy or generosity is too la- dicrou*.

I bad not the advantage of reading the lead ing article in your paper on which "Britanni- ous" comments, bot I gather from his remarks sufficient to enable me to infer that it related to the snpposed disloyalty of Great Britain to her Colonies. I think that, under the present Government, and with suoh a House of Commons as we nniortunately now have, there is too muoh ground for aueh s charge. Is it to be wondered at that the Colonies should chafe and fret when they are exposed to the false and scandalous aoousations of men like Kiar Hardie, Byles, Ward, ed id genus omne—and even of "Britannious" himself Î—Yours faithfully,

div.head: NILE VALLEY (NEW) COMPANY'S OPERATIONS.
div.p: Messrs, Lake and Currie, the company's engineers, report a* follows : - The total foot age for the month ended 30th November, 1906, amounted to 60 ft 6 ins. This low figure is aooounted for by the fact that nearly all the faoes were practically at a standstill for want of labour, very good progress was made here, the shaft being sank a farther 88 ft, making the total depth 395 ft 9 ins. Drive C fl advanced 5 ft to a total distance of 64 ft from the main shaft crosscut. Average width of lode 14 ins, average value 3.2 dwt*. Winze C N « sunk a farther 11 ft (Hnr, making tbetotal depth 38 ft 6 ins. Average width of lode 14.5 ins. Average 8.8 dwts. Winze B 3 2 was sunk an additional 6 ft, the total depth being now 99 ft Only a few days' work was possible in drive C S and winzes CN 1 and B 8 2, whilst no advance was made in any of the other faoes. In addition to the above, the rise* A N and A S 3. wirze A N 2 have been timbered, and passes have been put in wines A 8 2 and A 8 5, and tha level timbered preparatory to stopiog.

div.head: Khedivial Mail S.S. Co.
div.p: ASSEMBLÉE ORDINAIRE La neuvième assemblée générale ordinaire de U Khédivial Mail S.3.Co. a eu lieu dernièrement à Londres sons U préddence de Sir Auckland Colvin. Noub en avons publié le 5 courant on compte rendu détaillé, dont noos donnons ioi an aperça.

Après leotare da rapport da conseil d'administration et de oelai des œnsears, le président a exposé en substanoe oe qui soit: ''L'exeroice a donné des résultats satisfaisants et a permis à vos administrateurs de faire progressé les «flaires de la Sooiété. L'événement oapital de l'année a été l'addition à la flotte de l'Osmanieb, paquebot de premier ordre qui, après avoir été à l'essai durant les deux derniers mois de l'exeroice, fait maintenant le sfrrice régulier entre Alexandrie et Constantinople. Deax antres vapeurs plus petits ont été achetés et incorporés à la flotte. "Comme vous le savez, le conseil va voas v soumettre la proposition d'augmenter le capital social. Cettè augmentation doit noos permettre ~ - de procéder anx remplacements qte néoeisite l'amélioration de notre service et de renforcer notre ligne de Port-Sondan.

"Le chemin de fer Port Soodan-Berber, onvurt l'année dernière, donnera saos auoun doute one forte impulsion à notre mouvement de paquebots sur cette ligne. Loi prévisions de l'année en conrs sont excellentes, les lignes méditer»- niennes continuent à noas donner an rendement aussi bon que poisibleet les antres n'ao- ousent aucune diminution. Après nne convention avec le gouvernement égyptien pour un service bimensuel entre Suez et Port Soudan, il aélé déoidé de rendre oe service hebdomadaire, oe qui a été fait vers le milieo de l'exeroice et

a naturellement augmenté la valeur de la pro- ' prrété sociale à Alex.n Irie et à 8nez. M. Parkinson, directeur géné»l à Alexandrie, mérite tons les éloges poor la fa£on dont il a dirigé les affaires, ainsi que tout son personnel.

"Arrivant enfin anx modifications à introduire aux statut*, je vais vous en exposer le but et les conséquences Anx termes ^des artioles existants, la sooiété n'est pas autorisés à payer une commission pour la garantie on (a souscription des actions offertes an pnblio. Votre conseil, après nn mûr examen de la question, vous propose de fixer à 7 pour cent le maximum de la commission à payer dans de telles ciroonstanoes. Relativement à l'addition d'un nouvel article 11b, elle se trouve également néoessitée par les statuts aux termes desquels il est indispensable de fixer le minimum k payer pour sonsorire kone nouvelle émission. Snr ce chapitre notre conseil estime qae 5 poor oent est an montant raisonnable. Le but des autres paragraphes de "b'' à "bv inclusivement est de fixer la date de publication des avis de convocation à U 'joors, an lien de 7, avant la date de l'assemblée, et d'établir que les porteur* de oertificata d'actions, pour pouvoir voter, devront déposer leurs certifiants dix jours avant la date fixée pour l'assemblée. Q iant aux porteurs de certificats ré-idant eu Angleterre, ils devront / déposer les leurs cinq joars avant la date de ^ l'assemblée. Les modifications cidesauB ont été .introduites en vue de faciliter anx porteurs de certificate l'assistance ou la représentation aux assemblées. L'article 53 disant qae l'avis de convocation doit être notifié aux actionnaires 7 jours avant l'assemblée devra naturellement être modifié dans le même sens."
Ceci dit, la parois est donnés par le président, à tons oeux qui ont quelques remarques à faire on quelques éclaircissements k demander.

M. Henley, toat en se montrant satisfait du rapport et de la gestion du Conseil, tait remarquer que les recettes de l'année ayant été inférieures de 20,000 £ à oelles de l'exeroice intérieur, il n'est peut-être pas de oiroons tanoe de distribaer, commi l'année passé*, an dividende de* 10 %: M.EKnley note i ce sojet une somme de 2,300 £ en moins portée à la réserve, ainsi qu'au emprunt de 81,000 £. 11 sappose que l'augmentation do oapital sooial, dont il est d'ailleurs partisan, pourra servir k éteindre cette dette. Il ajoute qu'il serait hier, dans nu avenir pins on moins éloigné, d'établir séparément le prix de l'actif social, bateaux,

. propriétés et antres, qui furent acquis en bloo lors de la conatitation de la sooiété. Cela est d'antant plus à souhaiter que la société va augmenter sa flotte. Bn terminant,#M. Henley émet le vœn qoe la nouvelle émission soit f réservés de préférence anx actionnaires aotoels.
A quoi M. Francis Allen répond que d'est là an point acquis.

Sar le fond de la question, le président ré pond qoe o'e«t dans l'intérêt de la Société, bd vue de U noavelle émission et parce que la situation finanoière le permet, qfie le conseil a déoidé de distribuer on dividende de 10 % aux aotions ordinaire*. Bu oe qui conoerne la Hi, tinction à établir entre les pequebot*, terrains et antres éléments de l'aotif sooial, cette que* tion devra être disootée par le conseil d'administration. Et, renvoyant à répondre ao tr, i- sième point à l'assemblée extraordinaire, le prérident termine en spécifiant que l'emprunt n'a rien à voir aveo la future émission. Il eit remboursable par annuités.
La discussion étant dose, le bilan et le rapport sont approuvéu
administrateurs sortants, qui sont réélus.
MM. Edwin Gathrie & Co. sont également i réélus oensears anx appointements de 40 livres par an.
Le dividende de 10% .di eolioo. ordra.im I thtM .ÿj* in ^ 00 ThDM1)1Ii
es ensuite voté. | t^e 0f 907, when the Annual

Report of the Directors and the Balanoe Sheet will be submitted to the Company for A l'assemblée extraordinaire, tenue ensuit I consideration, and the ordinary business will pour procéder & la modification des statuts, Ip I be transacted, viz.:—
président dit qu'il n'a rien à ajouter à oe qu'il a déjà dit à la précédente assemblé*, maie qu'il sera heureux de répondre aux objeotion* ou remarques, qui pourraient être soulevées.

M. Maoray demande alors si oe u'est pas uu signe defaiblesse de la part delà sooiété de payer une commission pour la garantie de l'émission. Il semble,;dit il, qu'une sooiété distribuant 10% à ses actions ordinaires, 6 1/2% à ses aotions privilégiées et 4 1/2 % à ses obligations, pourrait se passer de commission pour le place meut de ses aotions.

Le président répond que si le conseil a de mandé l'autorisation de donner une commission cela ne veut pas dire qu'il osera de oe droit Bn demandant à l'assemblée de voter la réto lotion y relative, le conseil a simplement voulu prendré ses précautions en vae d'assurer le sucoès de l'émission.

point of its connection with the Egyptian j State Railway at Khargeh Junction (between j Abu Tisht anti Farshut) to Khargeh in | the Oasis of Khargeh, a distance of about J 120 miles (==;194 kilometres); and in order to * enable the Corporation to bring into full cul- f tivation and into a state of readiness for sale,

! simultaneously with the active mineral exploitation and development, the extensive lands of the Oases to be acquired in virtue of the concessions. The land after reclamation will be sold either immediately or after holding for a period for enhancement in value, and the entire purcliase moneys will be received by the Corporation. Taking a very conservative estimate, an average profit of at least £10 per feddan, equivalent to a profit of £200,000 on each of the 30 annual grants of 20,000 feddans, is to be anticipated after the completion of the Railway when the Corporation is placed in a position to proceed with sales.

div.head: Alexandria Water Company Limited.
div.p: AVIS

La Compagnie a l'honneur d'informer le Pablio que Moasiear J. E Cornish, Admi- nistra'ear-Direotear de la Compagnie, ayant manifesté le désir, motivé par son état de santé, de se démettre de ses fonotions de Direotenr, le Conseil s'est vo, bien à regret, obligé de faire droit à sa demande, mais il le prie d'accepter la Présidence du Conseil que Monsieur A. Z rvodachi lui a spontanément offerte, pour conserver à la Compagnie son préoieux conoours.
Le Conseil a nommé anx fonotions de Direotenr de la Compagnie Mr. Blagden, actuellement ingénieur en Chef et à celles de Directeur-adjoint Monsiear James Easton Cornish.
Mr. H.RC. Blagden signera sen), mais la signature de Mr. J. Easton Cornish devra être accompagnée de celle dn Chef da bureau ou du Caissier.
Les quittances d'abonnement seront signées con me toujours, par le Chef da Bureau et le Caissier.
Pour l'Alexandria Water Company, Limited.
Par ordre da Conseil,
J. Easton Cornish
Secrétaire
